Violation_Type: Failure to demonstrate new risk conditions
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 115 and Section 101(1)(a)
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed rape-related scars as new evidence; RPD had previously considered rape allegations; no significant new evidence or personalized risk identified in Albania
Procedural_Issue: Alleged lack of consideration of new evidence on gender-based violence and procedural fairness in PRRA decision
Evidence_Used: Rape-related scars, allegations of gender-based violence, risk of blood feud in Albania
Evidentiary_Deficiency: No significant new evidence presented; prior allegations already assessed by RPD
Credibility_Assessment: Officer found no credible, individualized risk based on new evidence
Decision_Outcome: PRRA denied
Outcome: Judicial review dismissed; no error found in Officer's decision
Relief_Sought: Overturn of PRRA denial, stay of removal
Remedy_Sought: Certification of a question of law; judicial review of PRRA decision
Decision_Rationale: PRRA not an appeal of RPD decision; requires demonstration of changed circumstances; no new evidence of personalized risk established

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the applicant meets the tri-partite test for a stay of removal (irreparable harm, serious issue to be tried, balance of convenience)
Crimes.Outcome: Application for stay of removal denied
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credibility undermined by previous misrepresentations and fabricated stories
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Affidavits, PRRA decision, past legal proceedings
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Tri-partite test and clean hands doctrine
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Alleged risks upon return to India
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to prove irreparable harm, lack of serious issue, balance of convenience favoring Minister, history of fraud
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Irreparable harm, serious issue to be tried, balance of convenience
Crimes.Application_Factor: History of immigration fraud and misrepresentation
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness and tri-partite test for interim relief
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Fabricated stories and misrepresentations in application

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the applicant meets the tri-partite test for a stay of removal
Crimes.Outcome: Application for stay of removal denied
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credibility undermined by past misrepresentations
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA provisions on enforceable removal orders and stay applications
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Alleged risk upon return to home country
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: No irreparable harm proven, no serious issue raised, public interest favors removal
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Judicial review and motion for stay
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to meet tri-partite test criteria
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Irreparable harm, serious issue, balance of convenience
Crimes.Application_Factor: History of misrepresentation leading to exclusion order

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the applicant meets the tri-partite test for a stay of removal
Crimes.Outcome: Application for stay of removal denied
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credibility undermined by previous misrepresentations and weak affidavits
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Tri-partite test for stay of removal
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Alleged risks upon return to India due to marriage fraud consequences
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of credible evidence, reasonable PRRA decision, public interest in removal
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Judicial review and motion for stay
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Irreparable harm, serious issue, balance of convenience

Evidence_Type: Hearsay - cited as concern by applicant
Evidence_Credibility: Assessed as reasonable by PRRA Officer
Credibility_Assessment: Found adequate and reasonable by the Court
Legal_Provision: State protection test under refugee law

Violation_Type: Refusal of protection based on risk assessment
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) - Protection obligations
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed risk of persecution in Turkey due to Kurdish ethnicity and political activities; PRRA officer assessed new evidence including a lawyer's letter and country reports
Claimant_Status: Protected Person or Applicant for Pre-Removal Risk Assessment (PRRA)
Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged inconsistency in applicant's evidence regarding arrests and involvement
Procedural_Issue: PRRA officer may have unreasonably dismissed key evidence (lawyer's letter on 1998 arrest)
Evidence_Used: Lawyer's letter confirming 1998 arrest, UK country report on treatment of activist Kurds, applicant's statements on political involvement
Evidentiary_Deficiency: PRRA officer found applicant's evidence unpersuasive; lack of corroboration on arrest claims
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's credibility questioned regarding past arrests and level of political activism
Decision_Outcome: PRRA application denied
Outcome: Judicial review dismissed; decision upheld despite error on one factual finding
Relief_Sought: Protection under PRRA due to risk of persecution, torture, or cruel and unusual treatment
Remedy_Sought: Quashing of PRRA decision and referral back for re-determination
Legal_Standard_Applied: Whether the PRRA officer's decision was reasonable under the standard of reasonableness
Decision_Rationale: Even if the finding on the 1998 arrest was unreasonable, the overall conclusion stands as arrests alone do not constitute persecution; country evidence indicates harassment but not systematic persecution

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa, had criminal record, claimed threats in home country
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Permanent Resident or applicant for PRRA
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Assessment of procedural fairness in PRRA decision
Evidence_Used: Criminal record
Claims of threats in Dominican Republic
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence of risk upon return
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claims not credible due to lack of supporting evidence
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness, unless procedural fairness issue arises
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No credible risk of torture or cruel treatment found; insufficient evidence

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work Permit Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Credibility and sufficiency of evidence in PRRA claim
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's evidence lacked credibility
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Risk of harm upon return to Dominican Republic
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Insufficient personal evidence and credibility concerns
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to provide sufficient credible evidence

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: IRPA - Risk of torture or cruel treatment (s. 115)
Crimes.Applicant_Criminal_Background: Yes, including cooperation with U.S. authorities
Crimes.Risk_Nexus: Claimed danger due to past cooperation with U.S. law enforcement
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Insufficient evidence of credible risk; delay in applying

Violation_Type: Failure to demonstrate personalized risk upon removal
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) subsection 72(1)
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed risk upon return to India based on speculative assertions about irregular travel documents and airport scrutiny without supporting evidence
Claimant_Status: Applicant in PRRA process following refugee claim rejection
Procedural_Issue: PRRA used to re-litigate previous decision rather than present new evidence of changed circumstances
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of significant new evidence showing changed country conditions or personal risk
Credibility_Assessment: Claims found speculative and lacking probative value
Decision_Outcome: PRRA application denied
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; no certification of general importance
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard in assessing officer's conclusion
Decision_Rationale: Officer's decision was reasonable as applicant failed to show significant change in circumstances or personalized risk

Application_Facts: PRRA officer excluded 20 documents deemed not 'new', despite letters from credible sources such as state officials providing significant corroboration of Mr. Elezi's claims.
Procedural_Issue: Exclusion of new evidence under subsection 113(a) without proper justification
Evidence_Used: 20 documents, including letters from credible sources like state officials
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to consider key corroborating evidence that was reasonably available or arose after the Board's rejection
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim rejected by the Board; PRRA application denied
Outcome: Judicial review granted; decision quashed; matter remitted for a new hearing with a different officer
Relief_Sought: Acceptance of refugee claim and protection
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review and a new PRRA assessment
Legal_Standard_Applied: Whether the PRRA officer correctly applied subsection 113(a) of the IRPA regarding new evidence
Decision_Rationale: The PRRA officer erred in excluding critical evidence that could significantly support the claimant's case, warranting a new hearing

Violation_Type: Failure to provide justification and address contradictory evidence
Legal_Provision_Violated: Principles of administrative reasonableness, transparency, and intelligibility in decision-making
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), principles of administrative law
Application_Facts: Tibor and Rebeka Pinter's refugee claims involved allegations of persecution; similar facts were assessed differently by the Board and PRRA
Procedural_Issue: Board failed to address PRRA findings, inconsistent reasoning on persecution in education and employment
Evidence_Used: PRRA decision finding persecution, Board's own findings on state protection
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to reconcile or explain discrepancies with PRRA decision
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claims rejected by the Board
Outcome: Unreasonable decision set aside
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of the Board's rejection of refugee claims
Remedy_Sought: Remittal of claims for reevaluation by a new panel
Decision_Rationale: Board did not justify its departure from PRRA findings despite similar facts; lack of transparency and intelligibility

Crimes.Crime_Name: Use of a fraudulent exit visa
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant used a fraudulent exit visa to leave Cuba and later returned to Cuba to transfer property, delaying her refugee claim.
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to use of fraudulent documents and return to country of origin
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Use of fraudulent exit visa indicates potential misrepresentation
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Lack of hearing transcript; issue of natural justice
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Affidavit testimony, travel history, timing of claim
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No transcript, but record sufficient for review
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Actions inconsistent with credible fear of persecution
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Judicial review of Refugee Division decision
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Credible fear of persecution, procedural fairness
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Delay in claiming refugee status and return to Cuba undermined credibility of fear of persecution

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee claim credibility and procedural fairness
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether misrepresentation affected credibility and whether procedural fairness was upheld
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant’s actions (return to Cuba, delay) inconsistent with genuine fear
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Testimony, documentary evidence, timeline of events
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Delay in making claim and return to country of alleged persecution
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Refugee hearing and subsequent judicial review
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Credible subjective fear supported by objective evidence
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None found; all relevant documents considered
Crimes.Application_Factor: Use of fraudulent documents and failure to disclose timely

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Credibility and procedural fairness in refugee claim
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Impact of missing hearing transcript on fairness and reviewability
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Subjective fear undermined by conduct inconsistent with persecution claims
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA provisions on misrepresentation and admissibility
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Return to Cuba and significant delay in claiming refugee status
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to provide transcript; however, no material prejudice found
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Whether decision can be reasonably reviewed without transcript
Crimes.Application_Factor: Use of fraudulent documentation and delayed claim
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Claim rejected based on lack of credibility

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Subsection 11(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants fled Sierra Leone due to civil war and remained in Canada after their visas expired
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review initiated due to alleged misapprehension of evidence
Evidence_Used: Evidence of harassment acknowledged by the Refugee Board
Sponsorship processing times
Applicants' age
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer failed to properly consider relevant evidence
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent residency based on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds under subsection 25(1)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer misapprehended evidence regarding hardship and processing delays

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with Immigration and Refugee Protection Act requirements
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Interpretation and application of humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Immigration Officer committed a reviewable error by misapprehending the evidence
Evidence_Type: Evidence of war-related flight from Sierra Leone
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Subsection 25(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate exemption from visa application requirements
Crimes.Application_Error: Misapprehension of evidence regarding processing times and hardships
Evidence_Ignored: Impact of long sponsorship processing times on elderly applicants
Crimes.Application_Factor: Age of applicants and length of sponsorship processing

Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 14 of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Application_Facts: Applicant does not speak English; interpreter errors affected key factual details such as dates and actions (e.g., 'pulled' vs. 'carried'); errors influenced credibility findings
Procedural_Issue: Interpreter errors during hearing
Evidence_Used: Transcript of hearing, expert affidavit on interpretation quality
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Inaccurate interpretation leading to factual inaccuracies in the record
Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility finding by the Board influenced by interpreter errors
Decision_Outcome: Refugee status denied by the Board
Outcome: Federal Court allowed judicial review, overturned decision
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of refugee status denial
Legal_Standard_Applied: Right to a fair hearing under s. 14 of the Charter
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness, with correctness for Charter issues
Decision_Rationale: Interpreter errors violated the applicant's right to a fair hearing, undermining the reliability of the credibility assessment
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Federal Court

Application_Facts: Applicant claimed bias due to witness involvement and procedural unfairness in RPD hearing
Procedural_Issue: Alleged breach of natural justice
Fair hearing concerns
Evidence_Used: Transcript of RPD hearing
Decision_Outcome: RPD decision found reasonable
No breach of natural justice
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Decision_Rationale: Applicant had ample opportunity to present arguments; no evidence of bias or unfairness found

Application_Facts: Applicant claimed refugee status due to domestic violence in Israel but faced credibility issues and insufficient evidence against state protection.
Procedural_Issue: Board's refusal to adjourn the hearing
applicant delayed proceedings multiple times
failed to secure counsel despite opportunities
Evidence_Used: Presumption of state protection in democratic Israel
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence to rebut the presumption of state protection
failed to provide clear evidence of inability to access state protection
Credibility_Assessment: applicant delayed proceedings and failed to secure counsel
Decision_Outcome: Board did not err in refusing the adjournment
concluded state protection was available
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Legal_Standard_Applied: Administrative tribunals have discretion to grant or deny adjournments based on specific factors
state protection is presumed unless claimant provides clear evidence of inability
Decision_Rationale: Applicant delayed proceedings, failed to secure counsel, and provided insufficient evidence to overcome the presumption of state protection in Israel

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA - Section related to authorized stay
Crimes.Application_Facts: Moumaev remained in Canada beyond the validity of his visa after fleeing Russia due to fear of persecution.
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Request for deferral of removal made post-overstay
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Reissued birth certificate indicating Chechen ethnicity
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer failed to consider new evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: New documentation supported ethnic identity, previously unverified
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Deferral of removal based on risk and new evidence
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Stay of removal pending PRRA application
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: As soon as reasonably practicable enforcement under IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Failure to consider exceptional circumstances rendered decision patently unreasonable
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Enforcement Officer, Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC)

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with removal order
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA - Section on enforcement of removal orders
Crimes.Application_Facts: Moumaev remained in Canada after a removal order was issued despite claiming risk upon return.
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Failed refugee claimant subject to removal
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Request for deferral based on new evidence not adequately assessed
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Restored birth certificate confirming Chechen origin
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer ignored new documentary evidence of ethnicity and risk
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Evidence deemed credible by Court despite prior doubts
Crimes.Outcome: Decision quashed; removal deferred pending second PRRA
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Deferral of removal based on humanitarian and protection grounds
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review and stay of removal
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Exceptional circumstances may justify deferral under IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Focus on non-compliance without assessing risk constituted error

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Eligibility for H&C consideration despite immigration violations
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 25(1)
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Birth certificate and personal history submitted to support claim
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: H&C application not yet decided; deferral sought
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate compelling circumstances
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Supporting documents strengthened credibility of ethnic and risk claims
Crimes.Legal_Rule: H&C considerations may override removal if exceptional circumstances exist
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Risk of persecution, family ties in Canada, rehabilitation
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Application pending; deferral granted via judicial intervention
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Reissued birth certificate, country condition reports
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA s.25(1) – Humanitarian and Compassionate grounds
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Enforcement officer prioritized compliance over H&C factors
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Deferral of removal to allow H&C assessment

Crimes.Crime_Name: Risk of persecution based on ethnicity
Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: IRPA, Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms, UN Convention Against Torture
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Persecution based on Chechen ethnicity in Russia
Crimes.Legal_Framework: International human rights law, domestic refugee protection statutes
Crimes.Institutional_Action: Removal order challenged on risk grounds

Crimes.Individual_Status_or_Claim: Chechen national fearing state and non-state persecution
Crimes.Targeted_Group: Chechens in Russia facing systemic discrimination and violence
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: Russia unable or unwilling to protect Chechen returnees
Crimes.Risk_Factor: History of torture, arbitrary detention, and extrajudicial killings of Chechens
Crimes.State_Protection_Adequacy: Inadequate protection in country of origin
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Serious harm including torture and persecution

Crimes.Violation_Type: Procedural failure in risk assessment process
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA - Sections governing PRRA and risk evaluation
Crimes.Application_Facts: Moumaev sought PRRA based on new evidence of Chechen ethnicity and risk
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Foreign national with prior negative refugee determination
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to overstaying and pending removal
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Failure to properly assess new evidence in PRRA context
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Reissued birth certificate establishing Chechen identity
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer disregarded material evidence relevant to risk
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: New evidence improved credibility of claim
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: PRRA refusal led to removal order enforcement attempt
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Stay of removal and re-assessment of risk
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Ignoring new risk evidence without justification is unreasonable

Application_Facts: Applicant claimed persecution by Syrian authorities after refusing to cover up tax fraud
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of the Commission's denial of refugee status based on lack of credibility
Evidence_Used: Applicant’s testimony
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of corroboration regarding subjective fear
Credibility_Assessment: Commission reasonably questioned credibility due to inconsistencies and delay
Decision_Outcome: Commission's decision to deny refugee status was reasonable
Outcome: Judicial review dismissed
Decision_Rationale: Doubts about subjective fear due to inconsistencies and delay in application

Crime_Name: Judicial Review of Visa Application Denial
Legal_Provision_Violated: Personal suitability assessment under economic factors
Application_Facts: Applicant lacked savings and ignored modern bookkeeping methods; jewelry was not liquid and irrelevant
Procedural_Issue: Assessment of motivation and adaptability during interview
Evidence_Used: Lack of assets, absence of computer skills, interview responses
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to provide proof of financial stability or technological adaptability
Credibility_Assessment: Officer found poor motivation based on lack of preparation and outdated practices
Decision_Outcome: Visa application denied
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Legal_Standard_Applied: Assessment of personal suitability including economic motivation and adaptability
Decision_Rationale: Officer validly considered lack of assets and computer skills as indicators of poor motivation and adaptability

Application_Facts: Mr. Chen was absent from Canada for 970 days, citing care for his ill mother and religious purposes
Residency_Compliance: Failed to meet physical presence requirement; absences deemed structural and voluntary
Procedural_Issue: Alleged error in interpretation of residency requirement and failure to consider relevant criteria by Citizenship Judge
Evidence_Used: Duration and nature of absences, family ties, Koo factors, purpose of travel
Credibility_Assessment: Absences not found to be humanitarian; deemed voluntary
Decision_Outcome: Appeal dismissed
Outcome: Mr. Chen remains ineligible for Canadian citizenship
Legal_Standard_Applied: Centralization of mode of existence in Canada
Decision_Rationale: The Citizenship Judge reasonably applied the residency requirements and considered relevant factors including Koo factors and nature of absences

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Civil dispute over asset preservation and bankruptcy jurisdiction
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether Almecon can pursue a preservation order against Anchortek and related parties despite BIA stay provisions
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Motion for preservation order in Federal Court post-bankruptcy
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: No evidence of specific trust fund or identifiable property; profits likely reinvested
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On Almecon to prove existence of trust or identifiable property
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Conduct of Anchortek’s principals criticized but not sanctioned
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Under BIA, no creditor may proceed against bankrupt debtor's property until trustee discharge; Section 71(2) vests all property in the trustee
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Application of statutory interpretation and procedural compliance under BIA
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Almecon claimed infringement profits were its property and subject to preservation
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim failed due to BIA stay and lack of identifiable trust property
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Absence of traceable funds, no documentation of trust, reinvestment of profits
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Federal Court Rules 377 and 378; BIA framework on creditor actions
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Respondents raised jurisdictional and procedural objections under BIA
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Preservation order against Anchortek and related parties
Crimes.Outcome: Motion dismissed with no costs awarded
Crimes.Legal_Provision: BIA s. 69.3, s. 71(2); Federal Court Rules 377, 378

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to cooperate in legal proceedings
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 69.3 of BIA; Federal Court Rules on preservation orders
Crimes.Governing_Law: Bankruptcy and Insolvency Act, Federal Court Rules
Crimes.Application_Facts: Almecon sought preservation of $350,000 allegedly linked to patent infringement profits
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Attempt to bypass automatic stay under BIA via preservation motion
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Court lacks jurisdiction due to vesting of property in trustee under BIA
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Allegations of misappropriation without proof of identifiable funds
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No traceable or distinct fund established; failure to lift stay
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Trustee and third parties resisted on valid procedural grounds
Crimes.Outcome: No relief granted; no costs awarded
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Preservation and disclosure of assets by trustee and third parties
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Preservation order under Federal Court Rules 377 and 378
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Requirement of identifiable property for preservation orders
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Statutory compliance with BIA and procedural rules
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Preservation orders unavailable where property is vested in trustee and no distinct fund exists

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Asset preservation dispute involving alleged misappropriation post-judgment
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Enforceability of preservation order against Respondents and Trustee under BIA
Crimes.Governing_Law: Bankruptcy and Insolvency Act, Sections 69.3 and 71(2)
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: No evidence of specific trust or separate fund; profits commingled
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On Almecon to establish trust or identifiable property
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Conduct of Anchortek’s principals criticized for asset transfers
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Section 69.3 BIA prohibits creditor action; Section 71(2) vests property in trustee
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Compliance with statutory stay and trust requirements
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Almecon claimed infringement profits were its property and subject to preservation
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim dismissed due to lack of jurisdiction and inapplicable remedies
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Lack of trust documentation, commingling of funds
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Resistance based on BIA jurisdictional and procedural bars
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Affidavit evidence, financial allegations without tracing
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Preservation order against Respondents and Trustee

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Alleged pre-bankruptcy transfer of assets to evade creditor claims
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether Almecon can obtain a preservation order under BIA and Federal Court Rules
Crimes.Governing_Law: Bankruptcy and Insolvency Act, trust law principles, Federal Court Rules
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Post-bankruptcy motion to preserve allegedly transferred assets
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: No proof of identifiable property or trust; inability to trace profits
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On Almecon to show fraudulent intent and identifiable property
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Anchortek’s principals’ conduct criticized for suspicious transfers
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Preservation requires identifiable property; trust property must satisfy three certainties
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Application of BIA stay and equitable remedy standards
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged fraudulent transfer of infringement profits before bankruptcy
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim failed due to lack of jurisdiction and unmet legal thresholds
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Absence of segregated funds, reinvestment patterns, no trust creation
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Jurisdictional and procedural resistance citing BIA protections
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Allegations of asset movement without documentary or financial proof
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Preservation order against third-party recipients of funds
Crimes.Legal_Provision: BIA s. 69.3, s. 71(2); Trust law on certainty of subject matter

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with immigration requirements
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the officer correctly applied the law in rejecting the PRRA application
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, subsection 113(a)
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Insufficient new evidence; previously available information not considered new
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to present new or previously unavailable evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Fear of persecution in Mexico not sufficiently substantiated
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Only new or previously unavailable evidence can be considered under subsection 113(a)
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of persecution by daughter’s father; family connections
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Alleged fear of persecution, state protection, internal flight alternative
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Applicant challenged officer's assessment via judicial review
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Affidavits, country condition reports, personal testimony

Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, subsection 113(a)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa, filed multiple refugee claims, mother later granted refugee status
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Failed refugee claimant, subsequent PRRA applicant

Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Admissibility of new evidence in PRRA process
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over PRRA decisions

Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Most evidence not deemed 'new' under subsection 113(a)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: PRRA officer found insufficient credible basis for fear claim
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Reassessment of PRRA application, protection from removal
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial intervention to overturn PRRA officer's decision
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Internal flight alternative and availability of state protection
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Existence of internal flight alternative and lack of new evidence
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: PRRA Officer, Federal Court on review

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Officer's failure to properly consider hardship evidence
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 25(1)

Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's evidence of inadequate care in Jamaica was credible but ignored

Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Hardship due to medical condition and lack of support

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant is a quadriplegic with no family in Jamaica and faces removal after criminal convictions
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Officer relied on undisclosed internet research without notifying applicant
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Internet research by officer not disclosed to applicant

Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Low risk due to physical disability
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Minimal threat due to physical limitations
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's medical condition supported by evidence

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Refusal based on disregard of hardship evidence and use of undisclosed research
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 25(1)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's claims supported by credible medical and social evidence
Evidence_Type: Evidence of inadequate care in Jamaica
Crimes.Legal_Provision: s. 25(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Extreme hardship upon return due to disability and lack of care
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of family support and medical infrastructure in Jamaica
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Contradictory evidence about care availability for disabled individuals
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Use of false passport at entry

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant remained in Canada beyond authorized stay
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Failed to comply with immigration status conditions
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Failure to disclose independent research to applicant
Evidence_Used: Undisclosed internet research
Applicant's H&C submission
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Ignored direct evidence on care for quadriplegics
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's evidence deemed credible

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possession of Cocaine with Intent to Transport
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Assessment of hardship and procedural fairness in refusal
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 25(1)
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Officer failed to properly weigh medical hardship evidence
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate H&C grounds
Crimes.Legal_Rule: s. 25(1) IRPA allows exemptions on H&C grounds
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Severe disability and lack of care in home country
Key_Evidence_Considered: Evidence of care facilities in Jamaica
Crimes.Outcome: Granted via court order for reconsideration

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Prior criminal convictions including violent offenses
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Severe physical disability limiting future risk
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Low likelihood of reoffending due to disability
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's health condition well-documented

Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act Violation
Legal_Provision_Violated: Rule 53 of the Refugee Protection Division Rules
Application_Facts: Applicant withdrew her refugee claim impulsively but later sought reinstatement due to fear of returning to Colombia.
Procedural_Issue: Withdrawal of refugee claim; delay in applying for reinstatement
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of evidence supporting reinstatement request
Decision_Outcome: RPD refused to reinstate the refugee claim
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review under subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Decision_Rationale: No breach of natural justice; delay and lack of evidence made reinstatement unreasonable

Violation_Type: Failure to meet criteria for Convention Refugee or person in need of protection
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed persecution due to imputed political activities and family association; alleged torture by Indian police
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of RPD decision
Evidence_Used: Applicant's testimony, claims of torture and persecution
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence linking claim to Convention grounds; lack of proof that state protection was unavailable
Credibility_Assessment: RPD found the applicant's claims not sufficiently substantiated
Decision_Outcome: RPD determined applicant was not a Convention Refugee nor in need of protection
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Relief_Sought: Recognition as a Convention Refugee or person in need of protection
Legal_Standard_Applied: Definition of Convention Refugee under s. 96 IRPA; Person in need of protection under s. 97 IRPA
Decision_Rationale: The RPD's conclusion was reasonable based on lack of sufficient evidence connecting the harm to a Convention ground and availability of state protection in India

Crimes.Crime_Name: Disobeying a lawful order under the Royal Canadian Mounted Police Act Regulations
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the R.C.M.P. Tribunal violates s. 11(d) of the Canadian Charter and s. 23 of the Quebec Charter due to lack of impartiality
Crimes.Governing_Law: Royal Canadian Mounted Police Act Regulations, Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms s. 11(d), Quebec Charter s. 23
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Officer refused to cooperate with investigation without legal counsel
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Not applicable – issue focused on legal interpretation
Crimes.Legal_Rule: s. 11(d) applies to criminal or quasi-criminal proceedings, not internal disciplinary matters; Quebec Charter does not apply to federal bodies
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Lack of impartiality and independence of tribunal
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Nature of penalties and purpose of tribunal
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Internal disciplinary process under federal jurisdiction
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Royal Canadian Mounted Police Act Regulations

Crimes.Crime_Name: Conduct unbecoming an officer under the Royal Canadian Mounted Police Act
Crimes.Governing_Law: Royal Canadian Mounted Police Act, Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms s. 11(d), Quebec Charter s. 23
Crimes.Application_Facts: R.C.M.P. officer refused to cooperate with investigation without legal counsel
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Applicability of provincial charter to federal body
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Record of refusal to cooperate during investigation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not central – matter based on legal characterization
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Distinction between criminal and internal disciplinary proceedings
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Proceedings are disciplinary, not penal; charters do not apply

Application_Facts: Applicants claimed Convention refugee status based on past persecution in Chile; Tribunal accepted credible evidence of past persecution but dismissed claim due to changed country conditions without addressing s. 2(3)
Procedural_Issue: Tribunal failed to consider s. 2(3) despite evidence of past persecution
Evidence_Used: Credible evidence of past persecution
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to assess compelling reasons arising from past persecution under s. 2(3)
Credibility_Assessment: The applicant's evidence was found credible
Decision_Outcome: Claim dismissed based on changed country conditions
Outcome: Judicial review allowed
Legal_Standard_Applied: Interpretation of s. 2(3) of the Immigration Act regarding continued refugee status despite changed country conditions
Decision_Rationale: The Tribunal erred in law by not considering s. 2(3) which requires assessment of compelling reasons arising from past persecution

Violation_Type: Failure to rebut presumption of adequate state protection
Legal_Provision_Violated: Sections 96 and 97(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Applicants faced threats from FARC after refusing to publish a book; reported threats to authorities but felt unprotected; Colombia struggles to protect targeted individuals despite efforts against FARC
Procedural_Issue: Board failed to consider specific risks faced by applicants
Evidence_Used: Evidence of threats from FARC, reports to authorities, country condition evidence on Colombia's protection capacity
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to adequately assess specific risks
Decision_Outcome: Board's decision found unreasonable
Outcome: Application allowed, decision set aside, case remitted for reconsideration
Legal_Standard_Applied: Convention refugee and person in need of protection under IRPA
Decision_Rationale: Board did not adequately assess the specific risks faced by the applicants despite evidence of threats and inadequate state protection

Application_Facts: Applicant claimed refugee status based on fear of persecution in Sri Lanka
Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged lack of credibility in testimony and supporting evidence
Procedural_Issue: RAD failed to conduct independent assessment of credibility; improperly relied on RPD findings
Jurisdictional_Issue: No jurisdictional error identified; issue pertains to standard of review
Evidence_Used: RPD's credibility findings, applicant's testimony, country condition reports
Credibility_Assessment: RPD found applicant not credible; RAD did not independently reassess
Decision_Outcome: RAD upheld RPD's negative credibility finding
Outcome: Judicial review allowed; decision quashed
Relief_Sought: Recognition as refugee, protection from removal
Remedy_Sought: Re-determination of refugee claim by a new RAD panel
Decision_Rationale: RAD incorrectly applied reasonableness by deferring to RPD without independent analysis; burden improperly placed on applicant

Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 25 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Principal Applicant's children would suffer potential harm if forced to leave Canada; Officer failed to inter-relate relevant factors concerning children's best interests
Claimant_Status: Principal Applicant (inland applicant for permanent residence)
Residency_Compliance: Compliant with residency requirements as an inland applicant
Procedural_Issue: Failure to conduct adequate, transparent, and intelligible analysis of humanitarian and compassionate grounds, particularly the best interests of children
Evidence_Used: Evidence of potential harm to children if removed from Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer did not adequately address or weigh evidence regarding children's best interests
Decision_Outcome: Application for permanent residence on humanitarian and compassionate grounds denied
Outcome: Judicial review granted; decision set aside
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of the refusal decision
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration of application by a different immigration officer
Legal_Standard_Applied: Best interests of the child under Section 25 of IRPA
Decision_Rationale: The Officer’s analysis was unreasonable due to lack of justification, transparency, and intelligibility in assessing the children's best interests
Authority_Responsible: Immigration Officer (decision remanded to a different officer)

Dispute_Type: Ownership of copyright in cigar designs
Legal_Issue: Whether Havana House can claim copyright without a written assignment
Procedural_Stage: Motion to strike out or request for particulars
Evidence_Assessment: Havana House failed to produce written assignments; Affidavits of Documents reviewed
Decision_Outcome: Claim not struck out; requirement to provide particulars within 15 days
Burden_of_Proof: On Havana House to substantiate copyright ownership
Credibility_Factor: Substantial doubt raised due to lack of written assignments
Legal_Rule: Assignment or grant of copyright must be in writing signed by the owner or agent
Standard_of_Review: Legal sufficiency of claim and supporting documentation
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged copyright ownership over Montecristo Habanas and Partagas cigar designs
Outcome_on_Merits: Not decided; claim allowed to proceed subject to provision of particulars
Key_Evidence_Considered: Affidavits of Documents, absence of written assignments
Defendant_Response: Moved to strike out portions of Statement of Claim or request particulars
Remedy_Requested: Striking out of claim or request for particulars
Outcome: Havana House must provide detailed particulars; cross-examinations permitted; costs shared equally
Authority: Court based on legal precedents and statutory interpretation

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the PRRA officer erred in determining Mr. Lebedev was not a Convention refugee or at personal risk of harm upon return to Russia
Crimes.Outcome: PRRA officer's decision quashed, case remitted for redetermination
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: PRRA officer dismissed credible evidence of systemic human rights abuses
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Evidence of systemic human rights abuses in Chechnya and harsh conditions in Russian prisons
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution due to potential military service in Chechnya
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Misinterpretation of objective country conditions and focus on applicant's 'resourcefulness'
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to properly assess personal risk and well-founded fear under IRPA
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Well-founded fear of persecution; personal risk of torture or cruel treatment
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Credible reports of systemic human rights violations in Chechnya and prison abuse in Russia
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Objective assessment of risk based on documentary evidence and country conditions
Crimes.Application_Factor: Applicant’s refusal to serve in military due to ethical concerns about human rights abuses

Crimes.Crime_Name: Using false documents for the purpose of entering Canada
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee status eligibility despite use of false documents
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether Vadim Lebedev is entitled to refugee status under IRPA s. 96 and s. 97 despite using false documents to enter Canada
Crimes.Outcome: PRRA decision quashed, case remanded for reassessment with legal questions certified
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: PRRA officer questioned the credibility of claims regarding personal risk and systemic abuses
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Reports on military hazing, prison conditions, and human rights violations in Chechnya
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution for refusing military service in Chechnya involving human rights abuses
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Misinterpretation of need for international condemnation and insufficient analysis of personal risk
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Judicial review following denial by Immigration and Refugee Board and PRRA application
Crimes.Application_Error: Flawed interpretation of legal standards and inadequate risk assessment under s. 97
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Objective risk of torture, cruel treatment, or death upon return
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Evidence of severe prison conditions and systemic military hazing in Russia
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Personal risk must be more than speculative; supported by objective evidence
Crimes.Application_Factor: Use of false documents justified by fear of conscription into abusive military operations
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Use of false documents to enter Canada

Legal_Issue: Whether the citizenship judge erred in assessing residency requirements and providing adequate reasons
Outcome: Decision found unreasonable; appeal allowed and case remitted
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant provided inconsistent evidence regarding residency
Evidence_Type: Residency records, applicant testimony, documentation of physical presence
Legal_Provision: Residency requirement of 1,095 days within four years under Citizenship Act
Basis_of_Claim: Alleged failure to meet physical presence requirement for citizenship
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of clarity on which residency test was applied and inadequate analysis of contradictory evidence
Proceeding_Type: Judicial review under Federal Courts Act
Application_Error: Failure to specify applicable residency test and reconcile inconsistencies in evidence
Evidence_Ignored: Contradictions in the applicant's residency claims
Legal_Standard: Residency duration and quality of connection to Canada
Application_Factor: Physical presence, qualitative attachment, centralization of existence
Decision_Outcome: Remanded to a different citizenship judge for reconsideration

Crimes.Crime_Name: False or misleading statements in tax returns
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Minister erred in denying relief under Subsection 220(3.1) of the ITA
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Applicant claimed ignorance and reliance on third-party advice; CRA found no extraordinary circumstances
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate extraordinary circumstances
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant's claim of misunderstanding not deemed credible or sufficient
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Subsection 220(3.1) allows waiver only under extraordinary circumstances beyond taxpayer's control
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Request for waiver of penalties and interest due to alleged misunderstanding
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Lack of compliance history, lack of due diligence, no evidence of extraordinary circumstances
Crimes.Legal_Framework: ITA and CRA policy guidelines (e.g., IC 92-2)
Crimes.Defendant_Response: CRA denied request based on absence of extraordinary circumstances
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary and declarative evidence regarding tax remittance practices
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Waiver of penalties and interest under ITA Subsection 220(3.1)

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to meet statutory payroll obligations
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant failed to remit CPP contributions, citing ignorance and third-party advice
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Taxpayer/employer subject to payroll deduction requirements
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Reliance on third-party advice without verification
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No proof of extraordinary circumstances or due diligence
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's claims not considered credible or sufficient
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Ignorance of law and third-party errors do not constitute extraordinary circumstances

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to withhold Canada Pension Plan contributions
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Minister erred in denying relief under Subsection 220(3.1) of the ITA
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Applicant cited ignorance and third-party advice; CRA found no extraordinary circumstances
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show undue hardship or extraordinary circumstances
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant's misunderstanding not accepted as valid defense
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Waiver allowed only under extraordinary circumstances or undue hardship
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Request for relief based on claimed ignorance and reliance on advisor
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Compliance history, due diligence, nature of error
Crimes.Defendant_Response: CRA maintained denial due to lack of qualifying circumstances

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to remit Canada Pension Plan contributions
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Minister erred in denying relief under Subsection 220(3.1) of the ITA
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Applicant failed to remit, paid penalties, claimed ignorance and third-party error
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On taxpayer to demonstrate eligibility for relief
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Claims of misunderstanding not supported by evidence of due diligence
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Subsection 220(3.1) requires extraordinary circumstances or hardship for relief
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Request for waiver due to non-compliance from misinterpretation of obligations
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Payment history, compliance record, explanation for failure
Crimes.Defendant_Response: CRA denied request citing lack of extraordinary circumstances

Legal_Issue: Whether the Commission reasonably dismissed the human rights complaint under paragraph 44(3)(b) of the Canadian Human Rights Act
Evidence_Assessment: No evidence of racial discrimination; termination due to misappropriation of funds
Decision_Outcome: Complaint dismissed
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show discriminatory basis
Legal_Rule: Commission may dismiss a complaint if inquiry is unwarranted or lacks jurisdiction
Outcome_on_Merits: No merit found; termination was non-discriminatory
Key_Evidence_Considered: Nature of misconduct (misappropriation), lack of discriminatory pattern
Legal_Framework: Human rights complaint process, federal jurisdiction
Defendant_Response: Termination based on financial misconduct, not race
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; Commission's decision upheld
Authority: Canadian Human Rights Commission, Federal Court

Legal_Issue: Whether the Commission reasonably dismissed the human rights complaint under paragraph 44(3)(b) of the Canadian Human Rights Act
Evidence_Assessment: Employee dismissed for 'kiting' and financial misconduct; no evidence of racial motivation
Decision_Outcome: Complaint dismissed
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to establish discriminatory intent
Credibility_Factor: Consistent disciplinary treatment of similar misconduct
Legal_Rule: Commission may dismiss complaint if no reasonable basis or non-discriminatory grounds
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged racial discrimination in dismissal for financial misconduct
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim unfounded; dismissal based on legitimate cause
Key_Evidence_Considered: Pattern of employee misconduct, 'kiting' practices, equal enforcement
Legal_Framework: Human rights complaint process, federal jurisdiction
Defendant_Response: Disciplinary action based on financial misconduct, not race
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; Commission's decision upheld
Authority: Canadian Human Rights Commission, Federal Court

Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Outcome: Commission erred on delay in indeterminate status and harassment during mediation
No error found on workspace accommodation
Decision_Outcome: Judicial review ordered referral of two issues to Tribunal
Upheld Commission's decision on workspace accommodation
Institutional_Action: Complaint dismissed by Canadian Human Rights Commission
State_Protection_Assessment: Partial failure in protection regarding status delay and harassment
Credibility: Evidence supported claims of discriminatory influence and inappropriate comments
Legal_Provision: Section 7(b) - Prohibition of adverse treatment based on disability
Section 14(1)(c) - Harassment based on prohibited grounds
Section 44(3)(b) - Commission's authority to dismiss complaints without referral
State_Protection_Adequacy: Inadequate for status delay and mediation harassment

Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Outcome: Complaint dismissed due to insufficient evidence
Decision_Outcome: Judicial review application denied
Protected_Group: Persons with disabilities, Women, Racialized individuals, Older persons
Targeted_Group: Individual based on disability, age, race, and gender
Credibility: Complainant provided submissions; investigation deemed thorough
Legal_Provision: Section 14 of the Canadian Human Rights Act (procedural fairness)
State_Protection_Adequacy: Sufficient investigation and opportunity to respond
Risk_Nature: Non-materialization of discrimination claim due to lack of evidence

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the inclusion of a fraudulent IELTS document constitutes material misrepresentation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Document was designed to mislead
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Submission of false documentation affecting immigration decision
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Potential to induce error in administration of the Act
Crimes.Application_Error: Inclusion of fraudulent document without applicant's knowledge

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether submission of a fraudulent IELTS result constitutes material misrepresentation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Document was designed to mislead
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Use of falsified language proficiency document
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Impact on integrity of immigration process
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to review application before submission

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review application by Minister challenging RPD's refugee status grant decision
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the RPD err in concluding that the Respondent's claim had a nexus to a ground in the Convention refugee definition?
Crimes.Outcome: Application dismissed; no serious general importance question certified
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Inconsistencies in testimony were noted but deemed non-fatal
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Testimony, evidence linking respondent to political opinion via association with MV Ocean Lady
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Perceived LTTE links due to travel on MV Ocean Lady
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Association with MV Ocean Lady leading to imputed political opinion
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard applies for mixed questions of law and fact
Crimes.Application_Factor: Nexus to 'political opinion' or 'particular social group'
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Misrepresentation in border documents regarding travel and affiliations

Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Risk of persecution due to political opinion
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Targeted due to perceived LTTE links
Crimes.Targeted_Individual: Respondent based on travel and ethnicity
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: RPD found narrative credible on key points

Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High risk of persecution due to identity and association
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Targeted due to Tamil ethnicity and MV Ocean Lady travel
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Credible evidence of past mistreatment and future risk
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: RPD accepted past mistreatment and future risk

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of RPD decision granting refugee status
Crimes.Criminal_Activity: Migrant smuggling via MV Ocean Lady
Crimes.Applicant_Criminal_Background: No indication of direct involvement in smuggling
Crimes.Grounds_for_Inadmissibility: Potential under IRPA for involvement in organized criminality
Crimes.Risk_Nexus: Persecution risk due to imputed political opinion
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Imputed political opinion due to travel on MV Ocean Lady

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of RPD decision granting refugee status
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Past torture and fear of future persecution
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA, Refugee Convention, international human rights law
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: Inadequate state protection in Sri Lanka
Crimes.Risk_Factor: History of torture and ongoing state persecution
Crimes.Credibility: Partially credible; inconsistencies noted but not fatal

Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of denial of taxpayer relief requests
Evidence_Assessment: Some applicants were genuinely unaware of reporting requirements; insufficient evidence for Gillespie
Decision_Outcome: Denial quashed for Lambert and Sobey; dismissed for Gillespie
Burden_of_Proof: On applicants to demonstrate grounds for reassessment
Credibility_Factor: Applicants' claimed unawareness of tax reporting obligations
Legal_Rule: Subsection 152(4.2) and paragraph 164(1.5)(a) of the Income Tax Act
Grounds_for_Claim: Unreported farming losses due to unawareness of reporting requirements
Outcome_on_Merits: Relief granted in part: remitted for reconsideration for Lambert and Sobey
Key_Evidence_Considered: Applicants' lack of awareness, reliance on court decision, CRA policy
Legal_Framework: CRA policies on reassessment beyond normal deadlines
Defendant_Response: Denial based on policy against reassessments solely due to court decisions
Remedy_Requested: Reassessment of tax returns for unreported losses
Outcome: Partial success: quashed and remitted for two applicants, dismissed for one
Authority: Minister's Delegate under the Income Tax Act

Legal_Issue: Can the applicant's time for appeal be extended due to administrative errors causing delayed notification of the Registrar's decision?
Evidence_Assessment: Trademark agents' errors led to delayed notification; no fault on applicant's part
Decision_Outcome: Extension of time for appeal granted
Burden_of_Proof: Applicant demonstrated genuine intention to appeal and arguable case
Credibility_Factor: Applicant acted diligently; no delay attributable to them
Legal_Rule: Section 56(1) allows appeal within two months or further time as court may allow
Standard_of_Review: Balance of justice and equitable discretion
Grounds_for_Claim: Administrative error by trademark agents causing late notice
Outcome_on_Merits: Opposition originally rejected by Registrar; appeal not yet decided on merits
Key_Evidence_Considered: Timing of notification, conduct of trademark agents, applicant’s intent
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence of correspondence and timelines
Remedy_Requested: Extension of time to file appeal
Outcome: Court allowed extension; applicant to pay respondent's costs and disbursements
Authority: Federal Court (implied from context of appeal under Trade-marks Act)

Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Outcome: Judicial review allowed
Legal_Framework: International human rights law, Refugee law
Decision_Outcome: Board's decision found unreasonable and set aside
Institutional_Action: Rehearing ordered by a different member of the Board
Credibility: Evidence provided was credible and corroborated
State_Protection_Adequacy: State protection deemed inadequate due to police disinterest and hostility
Risk_Nature: Serious harm including physical attacks and systemic discrimination
Perpetrator_Entity: Private individuals, lack of state intervention
Victim_Basis: Membership in a particular social group (homosexuals)

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility on grounds of serious criminality under IRPA
Legal_Issue: Jurisdiction of IAD to hear constitutional challenges
Decision_Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Legal_Rule: Sections 64 and 190 remove appeal rights for permanent residents inadmissible due to serious criminality
Legal_Framework: IRPA, Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Outcome: Appeal dismissed; IAD lacks jurisdiction

Crimes.Criminal_Activity: Extortion, threats, retaliation by MS gang
Crimes.Risk_Nexus: Personalized risk due to reporting gang activity

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Retaliation for reporting gang, witness to murder
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Positive
Accepted by Board
